items.title: Australian film producers and experts call Trump tariff proposal ‘bizarre’ and impossible to enforce
items.standfirst: US president threatens levy on all foreign-made films, but experts point out that the industry is global and Australia is intertwined with HollywoodFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastThe federal government has vowed to fight a proposed 100% tariff on Australian-made films after the US president, Donald Trump, posted on his social media platform that he planned to go ahead with the huge levy “on any and all movies made outside the United States”.Industry experts have described the proposal as bizarre and virtually impossible to enforce, given the global nature of film, with production, financing and post-production often spread across several countries. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Nicole Kidman files for divorce from Keith Urban citing ‘marital difficulties and irreconcilable differences’
items.standfirst: Divorce papers filed in Nashville court include detailed plan for shared childcare of their daughtersFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastNicole Kidman has filed for divorce from Keith Urban after 19 years of marriage, bringing a surprising end to a long and seemingly successful union that brought together two superstars from the worlds of movies and music.The 58-year-old Oscar-winning actor petitioned on Tuesday to end her marriage to the 57-year-old Grammy winning country singer in a Nashville court. The documents state the couple has undergone “marital difficulties and irreconcilable differences”. Continue reading...

The documents state the couple has undergone “marital difficulties and irreconcilable differences”. Continue reading...

items.title: Optus boss ‘has a lot of work to do’, Anika Wells says after meeting telco in wake of triple-zero outages
items.standfirst: Minister asks parent company to appoint external reviewer in attempt to restore Australians’ faith in emergency callsFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastThe government has asked Optus’s parent company to appoint an external reviewer to hold Optus to account after triple-zero outages this month, to address the “serious lack of confidence” Australians have in the telco.The prime minister, Anthony Albanese, said Optus had “let down its customers and has let down the nation” after two outages in less than a fortnight piled political and public pressure on the company. Continue reading...

items.title: Federal class action lodged over ‘racially discriminatory’ work for the dole scheme
items.standfirst: The community development program required those in remote areas – mostly Indigenous people – to work more than city-based participantsFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastA class action seeking compensation for about 20,000 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who were part of a work for the dole scheme that made remote participants work longer hours under more onerous conditions than people in the cities has been lodged in the federal court.The community development program required remote participants to work up to 50 hours a fortnight, five days a week, 52 weeks a year as a condition of income support. More than 80% of participants were Indigenous. Continue reading...
items.content: The community development program required those in remote areas – mostly Indigenous people – to work more than city-based participantsFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastA class action seeking compensation for about 20,000 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who were part of a work for the dole scheme that made remote participants work longer hours under more onerous conditions than people in the cities has been lodged in the federal court.The community development program required remote participants to work up to 50 hours a fortnight, five days a week, 52 weeks a year as a condition of income support. More than 80% of participants were Indigenous. Continue reading...

clusters.title: More sunscreens pulled as TGA reveals results as low as SPF4
clusters.neutral_headline: More Sunscreens Pulled Due to SPF Concerns

items.title: More sunscreens pulled as TGA reveals results as low as SPF4
items.standfirst: More sunscreens have been temporarily pulled from sale or paused from supply over sun protection claim concerns, bringing the total number of affected sunscreens currently off the market to 18.
items.content: More sunscreens have been temporarily pulled from sale or paused from supply over sun protection claim concerns, bringing the total number of affected sunscreens currently off the market to 18.The nation's medicines regulator, the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), issued the advice yesterday while revealing six more products had been voluntarily removed from its register in the past two weeks.It's the latest chapter in the saga sparked by a June Choice report that claimed more than a dozen popular sunscreens "failed" to meet their own SPF claims.READ MORE: The one thing that's even more important than your sunscreen's SPF ratingThe TGA yesterday said it had received preliminary test results on the base formulation used in Ultra Violette Lean Screen SPF50+ and an export-only variant – both of which the company voluntarily recalled in August – and 19 other products from 13 other companies. Those tests found the formula was unlikely to have an SPF of more than 21 and "may, for at least some of the goods, be as low as SPF four".The TGA said manufacturer Wild Child Laboratories had stopped manufacturing and supplying the base formulation but each sunscreen company would be carrying out its own tests."The TGA is considering whether to take regulatory action with respect to those sunscreens," it said."Each company is provided with an opportunity to respond to any proposed regulatory action before the TGA makes a decision."The TGA also issued a warning about UK-based testing laboratory Princeton Consumer Research, saying it had "significant concerns" about the reliability of its tests.It said "many" companies using the Wild Child-made base formula had – before being told of the regulator's concerns – relied on tests performed by PCR to support their SPF claims.Wild Child Laboratories said the TGA had confirmed "no manufacturing issues were identified at our facility that could explain variability in SPF testing results" and said the discrepancies were "part of a broader, industry-wide issue"."We understand the TGA has raised concerns about testing undertaken by PCR Corp and is conducting an ongoing investigation," chief executive Tom Curnow told 9news.com.au in a statement."Wild Child has ceased using PCR and initiated confirmatory testing with other accredited, independent laboratories to validate the SPF performance of our products."We remain committed to transparency, product safety, and supporting the introduction of more consistent and objective SPF testing standards across Australia."The TGA said it had written to PCR but had not received a response. 9news.com.au has contacted PCR for comment.The TGA yesterday released a list of sunscreens using the same base formulation. It stated that where the company responsible for a sunscreen has decided to cancel or recall the affected goods, it is working to support them in doing so.It also advised consumers who purchased a product from the list that they may wish to consider using an alternative product until the TGA completes its review.S kincare brand Naked Sundays yesterday said it had commissioned more independent testing for its Collagen Glow Mineral Sunscreen, which uses the same base formula but wasn't tested in the Choice report."Preliminary results for Collagen Glow have now been provided to the TGA, confirming our variant provides high sun protection, poses no concern, and we will await further guidance from the regulator," it said."Naked Sundays partners with various manufacturers in the US and Australia, and no other Naked Sundays products in Australia and or worldwide are impacted," the company said."Naked Sundays is working closely with the TGA to ensure we uphold the highest standards for all our products, and we will adopt any new testing requirements that the TGA may impose as soon as they are in place."Of the 21 products sharing the same base formulation, only two remain on the market in Australia: Allganics Light Sunscreen SPF50+ and GlindaWand The Fountain of Youth Environmental Defence Cream SPF50+.The others have all been either voluntarily recalled and cancelled from the regulator's register or temporarily pulled from sale.You can find a full and regularly updated list of the sunscreens using the Wild Child base formulation on the TGA website.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

The removals are due to sun protection claims.

clusters.title: Family 'devastated' as search continues for missing boy Gus
clusters.neutral_headline: Search Continues for Missing Four-Year-Old Boy Gus

items.title: Family 'devastated' as search continues for missing boy Gus
items.standfirst: T he four-year-old has not been seen since he was playing on his family's homestead on Saturday.
items.content: The search for missing little boy Gus continues in mid-north South Australia today.The four-year-old was last seen playing on his family's homestead, about 40km south of Yunta, at 5pm last Saturday.Gus is described as Caucasian, with long, blonde, curly hair.READ MORE: China bans all BHP iron ore shipments amid pricing row He was wearing a grey sun hat, a cobalt blue t-shirt with a yellow Minion character on the front, light grey long pants, and boots. Police and emergency services have searched the area since Saturday night, but have not been able to find the boy.Aerial searches have continued throughout the nights, while ground searches in daylight hours have included SES, trail bikes, ATVs, dogs, and a drone.READ MORE: Renters taking major steps to pay less to landlords Water police and mounted police joined the search yesterday as it expanded to include dams and tanks on the property. Gus's family issued a statement yesterday ."We are devastated by the disappearance of our beloved Gus on Saturday afternoon. This has come as a shock to our family and friends, and we are struggling to comprehend what has happened," the family said.READ MORE: Why couple raced the clock to buy before new first home buyers scheme "Gus's absence is felt in all of us, and we miss him more than words can express. Our hearts are aching, and we are holding onto hope that he will be found and returned to us safely."The family thanked police and volunteers and asked for privacy as the search continued. Anybody with information is urged to contact Crime Stopperrs on 1800 333 000 or online, and quote the reference number 250513. DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.content: Police are continuing to search for Gus, who vanished while playing at his family's homestead near Yunta in a remote part of South Australia's north.

The search is entering its fifth day.

clusters.title: Qantas international flight carrying 400 passengers makes U-turn
clusters.neutral_headline: Qantas Flight Returns to Sydney Due to Technical Issue

items.title: Qantas international flight carrying 400 passengers makes U-turn
items.standfirst: T he A380 jet had been in the air just over four hours when it was forced to turn back to Sydney.
items.content: More than 400 passengers will be put on a replacement flight today, after their plane from Sydney to Johannesburg in South Africa was forced to turn around.The Qantas A380 passenger jet was four and a half hours into the flight and over the south of Tasmania when it turned back to Sydney last night due to a fault with satellite communications.No mayday or any emergency call was made.READ MORE: Federal government's first home buyer scheme kicks off today The A380 has returned to Sydney to be reviewed by an engineering team, who will determine the cause of the faultAll passengers were offered accommodation and are expected to complete their journey to Johannesburg by taking another flight at 1pm today.A Qantas spokesman said the carrier thanked the passengers for their patience and understanding. DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

clusters.title: China bans all BHP iron ore shipments amid pricing row
clusters.neutral_headline: China Halts BHP Iron Ore Shipments Amid Pricing Dispute

items.title: China bans all BHP iron ore shipments amid pricing row
items.standfirst: T he move came as talks between the mining giant and China's state-run iron ore trader stalled.
items.content: China has banned one of Australia's largest export commodities, putting a halt on BHP iron ore cargoes amid a deepening pricing dispute.State-run iron ore trader China Mineral Resources Group (CMRG) urged local mills to temporarily pause purchases of any dollar-denominated seaborne iron ore cargoes from BHP, reports Bloomberg News.The move comes as contract talks between the Australian miner and Chinese buyers stall.READ MORE: How Labor's fast-tracked 5 per cent deposit Home Guarantee Scheme will actually workCMRG was created to bolster China's influence in the global iron ore market, and this move further highlights Beijing's determination to gain greater sway over prices.Iron ore is a key ingredient in steel production, and Chinese demand for it has been instrumental in Australia's economic prosperity, accounting for up to 5 per cent of the country's gross domestic product.Last financial year iron ore exports were worth about $138 billion.BHP is the world's biggest listed mining company and is a major player in the Australian share market .A spokesperson for BHP said the company couldn't comment on commercial arrangements.Last month, the mining giant said its annual profit dipped to the lowest in five years amid slowing demand from China impacted iron ore prices. - With Reuters Sign up here to receive our daily newsletters and breaking news alerts, sent straight to your inbox.

items.title: Rocky ride for BHP shares after report of China ban

items.content: BHP shares slumped in London overnight on a report China’s state-run iron ore buyer has told major steelmakers and traders to temporarily halt purchases of all new cargoes from the mining giant.

items.content: China has banned one of Australia's largest exports, putting a halt on BHP iron ore cargoes amid a pricing dispute.
